instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CPU_VR_EN: What is CPU_VR_EN? CPU_VR_EN is an enable signal for CPU VCORE that is present when it is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. ALL_SYS_PWRGD, PM_RSMRST_L, PM_SLP_SUS_L, and PM_SLP_S3_L are necessary prerequisites for CPU_VR_EN to be present. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power No Chime No <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Liquid damaged macbook Air

Wine spill on keyboard

no major areas of damage that I can tell, Most damage I can see was 2 slightly blackened pins on the keyboard connector and some dried wine spots on the board.

Board has only been scrubbed in the small spots where wine was dried. Has not been through UC. 

All main rails are there but CPU power is not turning on.

Not too familiar with the power sequence for CPU VCC.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power No Chime No <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL> present????? Voltage on pin 16 and 17 from <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>???

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power No Chime No <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Also inspect pin 8 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> very closely.

threads.message:
Pin 16 is 5v and pin 17 are 8.4v

Looking now at the other area

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power No Chime No <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Checked all resistors on the page that are directly tied to <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> all within spec. <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> Pin 3 output 3.378V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power No Chime No <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_S0</SIGNAL>
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power No Chime No <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Got VCC CPU now. <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> had wine under it bridging pads. CPU is now 1.78V. Testing boot now

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power No Chime No <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Computer boots now. No backlight but I think its just the diode on the boost circuit is bad.

Thank you guys so much. I now know how the circuit works a little more.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power No Chime No <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Diode never goes bad. Probably dead <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> or feedback trace.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power No Chime No <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You were correct Duke. Feedback had no continuity. Ran a jumper all is good.
